title: 105_s2433
content: TITLE X--FINANCIAL INFORMATION PRIVACY PROTECTION is added to the Consumer Credit Protection Act to enhance financial information privacy. The Financial Information Privacy Act includes sections on short title, definitions, privacy protection, enforcement, civil liability, criminal penalty, relation to State laws, and agency guidance. The Act aims to protect customer information of financial institutions. The Financial Information Privacy Act defines a customer as any person to whom a financial institution provides a product or service, including acting as a fiduciary. Customer information of a financial institution refers to any information derived from the relationship between the institution and a customer. The term 'customer information of a financial institution' refers to any information maintained by a financial institution that is derived from the relationship with a customer and is identified with the customer. The term 'document' includes any information in any form. A financial institution is defined as any institution providing financial services to customers with financial accounts. The term 'financial institution' encompasses institutions providing financial services to customers with credit, deposit, trust, or other financial accounts. This includes depository institutions, loan or finance companies, and credit card issuers. The term 'financial institution' includes depository institutions, loan or finance companies, credit card issuers, and consumer reporting agencies. The Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System may further define this term through regulations. The Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System may define 'financial institution' through regulations for privacy protection of customer information. It is prohibited to obtain customer information by false pretenses. It is a violation to obtain customer information from a financial institution through false pretenses, such as making fraudulent statements to deceive employees or customers. The violation involves deceiving a financial institution's officer, employee, or agent by making false statements or providing forged documents to obtain customer information. The provision prohibits knowingly providing forged or fraudulent documents to deceive financial institution personnel into releasing customer information. The provision prohibits soliciting someone to obtain customer information from a financial institution under false pretenses, with exceptions for law enforcement agencies. The provision prohibits obtaining customer information from a financial institution under false pretenses, with exceptions for law enforcement agencies and certain cases involving financial institutions. Cases.--No provision of this section shall prevent a financial institution, officer, employee, or agent from obtaining customer information for security testing, investigating misconduct, or recovering lost information. Compliance with this title shall be enforced by the Federal Trade Commission in the same manner as the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act. The Fair Debt Collection Practices Act authorizes the Commission to enforce compliance. Enforcement for national banks and Federal branches is under the Federal Deposit Insurance Act. Compliance with this title is enforced by the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency for national banks and member banks of the Federal Reserve System. The Office of the Comptroller of the Currency enforces compliance for national banks and member banks of the Federal Reserve System, while the Board enforces compliance for other entities like branches and agencies of foreign banks. The Board oversees lending companies owned by foreign banks, organizations under the Federal Reserve Act, banks insured by the FDIC (excluding Federal Reserve System members and national nonmember banks), and insured State branches of foreign banks. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation oversees banks insured by the FDIC, while the Office of Thrift Supervision oversees savings associations. The National Credit Union Administration administers the Federal Credit Union Act for Federal credit unions. The Office of Thrift Supervision oversees savings associations, and the National Credit Union Administration administers the Federal Credit Union Act for Federal credit unions. The Federal Trade Commission or relevant agencies have the authority to intervene in State actions for violations of the title, including conducting investigations and administering oaths. Additionally, during federal action, no State can bring an action under this section. "During a civil action by the Federal Trade Commission or relevant agencies for a violation of this title, no State can bring a separate action against the same defendant for the same violation. Non-compliance with this title regarding financial institutions or customer information may result in civil liability for individuals." "Sec. 1005 of the title states that any person failing to comply with provisions regarding financial institutions or customer information is liable for actual damages sustained by the financial institution or customer." The liability for failing to comply with financial institution or customer information provisions includes actual damages, additional damages determined by the court, and attorneys' fees for successful cases. Sec. 1006 outlines the criminal penalties for violating section 1003, including fines or imprisonment for up to 5 years. Enhanced penalties apply to aggravated cases. Sec. 1006 imposes criminal penalties for violating section 1003, with fines or imprisonment up to 5 years. Enhanced penalties apply to aggravated cases involving other laws or illegal activities exceeding $100,000 in a 12-month period. Sec. 1007 clarifies that the title does not override state laws unless they conflict with it. Sec. 1008 states that Federal banking agencies must provide guidance to further the objectives of the title. Sec. 1008 requires Federal banking agencies to issue advisories to depository institutions to help prevent prohibited activities under section 1003. The Comptroller General must report to Congress within 18 months of the enactment of this Act. Before the end of the 18-month period, the Comptroller General will submit a report to Congress on the efficacy of remedies in addressing fraudulent attempts to obtain financial information. Recommendations for additional legislative actions may also be included. The Comptroller General will report to Congress on the effectiveness of remedies in addressing fraudulent attempts to obtain financial information and may suggest further legislative or regulatory actions to protect financial privacy.
